module.title: the – definite article
module.p: There are four basic forms of the definite article in Gaelic –
These forms agree with the gender/number and case of the following noun –
The precise pronunciation (and written representation) of each form of the Gaelic definite article depends on the initial sound of the following word –

ul.li:
leniting an –
If the following word begins with p-, c-, b-, g-, m-, the word is lenited and the form of the article changes to a’.
If the following word begins with f-, the word is lenited.
If the following word begins with s- followed by a vowel, -l-, -r- or -n-, it is prefixed by t-.

non-leniting an –
If the following word begins with a labial consonant (i.e. p-, b-, f-, m-), the form of the article changes to am.
If the following word begins with a vowel, it is prefixed by t-.

na –
If the following word begins with a vowel, it is prefixed by h-.

nan –
If the following word begins with a labial consonant (i.e. p-, b-, f-, m-), the form of the article changes to nam.

module.p: Here are example paradigms for all combinations of gender, part-of-speech and initial sound –

ul.li: masculine nouns – ainm, balach, blaigeard, broc, ceann, cladh, cnoc, crùn, duine, dlùth, dream, eilean, fear, flùr, freumh, gille, glutaire, gnog, grèim, ionad, loch, mac, naomh, òran, peann, ploc, prionnsa, ràmh, sabhal, sgàthan, sglèatair, sgread, sloc, spiorad, spleadh, spreadhadh, sruth, stoc, structair, taigh, tlus, tnù, traon, ubhal
feminine nouns – abhainn, buthaid, bliadhna, bràiste, caileag, clach, cnò, croit, deoch, dlòth, drochaid, eaglais, fairge, fleasg, fras, geug, glùn, gnùis, greis, iuchair, làmh, muc, nathair, sùil,
ordinals – dàrna, treas, ceathramh, còigeamh, siathamh, seachdamh, ochdamh, naoidheamh, deicheamh, aonamh, ficheadamh, lethcheudamh, ceudamh, mìleamh
new ordinals – tritheadamh, ceathradamh, caogadamh, seasgadamh, seachdadamh, ochadamh, naochadamh
cardinals – trì, ceithir, còig, sia, seachd, ochd, naoi, deich
adjectives – deagh, droch, seann, dearbh, fìor, sàr

module.p: However, there are some notable exceptions to these rules regarding definite article agreement in modern Gaelic –

ol.li: In the nominative masculine singular, the t- is usually dropped nowadays before adjectives and numerals (and perhaps even prefixes) starting with a vowel, e.g. thàinig an ath fhear a-steach the next man came in, cf. aon, ath
When followed by the ordinal numeral ciad first, the nominative singular definite article is always a’, even when the noun is masculine, e.g. thàinig a’ chiad fhear a-steach the first man came in
When followed by the cardinal numeral dà, the genitive feminine definite article is nowadays an rather than na, e.g. comar an dà aibhne the confluence of the two rivers

box.title: definite article + ainm
box.p: ainm name is a masculine noun starting with the vowel a(i)-

box.title: definite article + balach
box.p: balach boy is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant b-

box.title: definite article + blaigeard
box.p: blaigeard scoundrel is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant b(l)-

box.title: definite article + broc
box.p: broc badger is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant b(r)-

box.title: definite article + ceann
box.p: ceann head is a masculine noun starting with the velar consonant c-

box.title: definite article + cladh
box.p: cladh cemetery is a masculine noun starting with the velar consonant c(l)-

box.title: definite article + cnoc
box.p: cnoc hill is a masculine noun starting with the velar consonant c(n)-

box.title: definite article + crùn
box.p: crùn crown is a masculine noun starting with the velar consonant c(r)-

box.title: definite article + duine
box.p: duine man is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant d-

box.title: definite article + dlùth
box.p: dlùth warp is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant d(l)-

box.title: definite article + dream
box.p: dream tribe is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant d(r)-

box.title: definite article + eilean
box.p: eilean island is a masculine noun starting with the vowel e(i)-

box.title: definite article + fear
box.p: fear man is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant f-

box.title: definite article + flùr
box.p: flùr flower is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant f(l)-

box.title: definite article + freumh
box.p: freumh root is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant f(r)-

box.title: definite article + gille
box.p: gille boy is a masculine noun starting with the velar consonant g-

box.title: definite article + glutaire
box.p: glutaire glutton is a masculine noun starting with the velar consonant g(l)-

box.title: definite article + gnog
box.p: gnog knock is a masculine noun starting with the velar consonant g(n)-

box.title: definite article + grèim
box.p: grèim grip is a masculine noun starting with the velar consonant g(r)-

box.title: definite article + ionad
box.p: ionad centre is a masculine noun starting with the vowel i(o)-

box.title: definite article + loch
box.p: loch lake is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant l-

box.title: definite article + mac
box.p: mac son is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant m-

box.title: definite article + naomh
box.p: naomh saint is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant n-

box.title: definite article + òran
box.p: òran song is a masculine noun starting with the vowel ò-

box.title: definite article + peann
box.p: peann pen is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant p-

box.title: definite article + ploc
box.p: ploc clod is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant p(l)-

box.title: definite article + prionnsa
box.p: prionnsa prince is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant p(r)-

box.title: definite article + ràmh
box.p: ràmh oar is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant r-

box.title: definite article + sabhal
box.p: sabhal barn is a masculine noun starting with the soft sybillant s-

box.title: definite article + sgàthan
box.p: sgàthan mirror is a masculine noun starting with the hard sybillant sg-

box.title: definite article + sglèatair
box.p: sglèatair slater is a masculine noun starting with the hard sybillant sg(l)-

box.title: definite article + sgread
box.p: sgread screech is a masculine noun starting with the hard sybillant sg(r)-

box.title: definite article + sloc
box.p: sloc pit is a masculine noun starting with the soft sybillant s(l)-

box.title: definite article + spiorad
box.p: spiorad spirit is a masculine noun starting with the hard sybillant sp-

box.title: definite article + spleadh
box.p: spleadh webbed foot is a masculine noun starting with the hard sybillant sp(l)-

box.title: definite article + spreadhadh
box.p: spreadhadh explosion is a masculine noun starting with the hard sybillant sp(r)-

box.title: definite article + sruth
box.p: sruth stream is a masculine noun starting with the soft sybillant sr-

box.title: definite article + stoc
box.p: stoc stump is a masculine noun starting with the hard sybillant st-

box.title: definite article + structair
box.p: structair structure is a masculine noun starting with the hard sybillant str-

box.title: definite article + taigh
box.p: taigh house is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant t-

box.title: definite article + tlus
box.p: tlus pity is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant t(l)-

box.title: definite article + tnù
box.p: tnù envy is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant t(n)-

box.title: definite article + traon
box.p: traon corncrake is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant t(r)-

box.title: definite article + ubhal
box.p: ubhal apple is a masculine noun starting with the vowel u-

box.title: definite article + abhainn
box.p: abhainn river is a feminine noun starting with the vowel a-

box.title: definite article + buthaid
box.p: buthaid puffin is a feminine noun starting woth the labial consonant b-

box.title: definite article + bliadhna
box.p: bliadhna year is a feminine noun sarting with the labial consonant b(l)-.

box.title: definite article + bràiste
box.p: bràiste brooch is a feminine noun starting with the labial consonant b(r)-.

box.title: definite article + caileag
box.p: caileag girl is a feminine noun starting with the velar consonant c-.

box.title: definite article + clach
box.p: clach stone is a feminine noun starting with the velar consonant c(l)-.

box.title: definite article + cnò
box.p: cnò nut is a feminine noun starting with the velar consonant c(n)-.

box.title: definite article + croit
box.p: croit croft is a feminine noun starting with the velar consonant c(r)-.

box.title: definite article + deoch
box.p: deoch drink is a feminine noun starting with the dental consonant d-.

box.title: definite article + dlòth
box.p: dlòth handful is a feminine noun starting with the dental consonant d(l)-.

box.title: definite article + drochaid
box.p: drochaid bridge is a feminine noun starting with the dental consonant d(r)-.

box.title: definite article + eaglais
box.p: eaglais church is a feminine noun starting with the vowel e(a)-.

box.title: definite article + fairge
box.p: fairge sea is a feminine noun starting with the labial consonant f-.

box.title: definite article + fleasg
box.p: fleasg garland is a feminine noun starting with the labial consonant f(l)-.

box.title: definite article + fras
box.p: fras shower is a feminine noun starting with the labial consonant f(r)-.

box.title: definite article + geug
box.p: geug branch is a feminine noun starting with the velar consonant g-.

box.title: definite article + glùn
box.p: glùn knee is a feminine noun starting with the velar consonant g(l)-.

box.title: definite article + gnùis
box.p: gnùis face is a feminine noun starting with the velar consonant g(n)-.

box.title: definite article + greis
box.p: greis while is a feminine noun starting with the velar consonant g(r)-.

box.title: definite article + iuchair
box.p: iuchair key is a feminine noun starting with the vowel i(u)-.

box.title: definite article + làmh
box.p: làmh hand is a feminine noun starting with the dental consonant l-.

box.title: definite article + muc
box.p: muc pig is a feminine noun starting with the labial consonant m-.

box.title: definite article + nathair
box.p: nathair snake is a feminine noun starting with the dental consonant n-.

box.title: definite article + sùil
box.p: sùil eye is a feminine noun starting with the soft sybillant s-.

box.title: definite article + dàrna
box.p: dàrna second is an ordinal numeral, starting with the dental consonant d-

box.title: definite article + treas
box.p: treas third is an ordinal numeral, starting with the dental consonant t(r)-

box.title: definite article + ceathramh
box.p: ceathramh fourth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the velar consonant c-

box.title: definite article + còigeamh
box.p: còigeamh fifth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the velar consonant c-

box.title: definite article + siathamh
box.p: siathamh sixth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the soft sybillant s-

box.title: definite article + seachdamh
box.p: seachdamh seventh is an ordinal numeral, starting with the soft sybillant s-

box.title: definite article + ochdamh
box.p: ochdamh eighth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the vowel o-

box.title: definite article + naoidheamh
box.p: naoidheamh ninth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the dental consonant n-

box.title: definite article + deicheamh
box.p: deicheamh tenth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the dental consonant d-

box.title: definite article + aonamh
box.p: aonamh first is an ordinal numeral, starting with the vowel a(o)-

box.title: definite article + ficheadamh
box.p: ficheadamh twentieth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the labial consonant f-

box.title: definite article + lethcheudamh
box.p: lethcheudamh fiftieth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the dental consonant l-

box.title: definite article + ceudamh
box.p: ceudamh hundredth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the velar consonant c-

box.title: definite article + mìleamh
box.p: mìleamh thousandth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the labial consonant m-

box.title: definite article + aon
box.p: The cardinal numeral aon one, only, same starts with the vowel a(o)- and interacts with the definite article as follows –
The most common nominative masculine form nowadays is an aon ...

li.gd: ’S e Tòmas an aon chroitear as aithne dhomh a dh’èirich gu inbhe taidhcùn.
li.en2: Thomas is the one crofter I have known who rose to the level of a tycoon.
li.ref: Dòmhnall Alasdair Dòmhnallach (2001) Sgeulachdan Dhòmhnaill Alasdair 5

li.gd: Gu mì-fhortanach cha b’ e MacRath an aon mhinistear a dh’fheuch ri coimhearsnachd anns na h-eileanan a chumail fo spòig.
li.en2: Unfortunately MacRae was not the only minister who tried to keep a community in the islands in his claws.
li.ref: Seonaidh Ailig Mac a’ Phearsain (2011) Steall à Iomadh Lòn 35

box.p: But an t-aon can still be found sometimes as well –

li.gd: Bha e turas anns an Sutha ann an Dun Eideann agus stad e aig ionad nan tìgearan. Cha robh ann ach an t-aon tìgear mòr agus e-fhèin ga choimhead.
li.en2: He was once in Edinburgh Zoo and he stood in the tiger enclosure. There was nobody there but the one large tiger and himself watching it.
li.ref: Iain MacLeòid (1992) An Sgaile Dhorcha 19

box.title: definite article + dà
box.p: The cardinal numeral dà two starts with the dental consonant d-, and takes the singular definite article as follows –
The usual genitive feminine form nowadays is ... an dà ...

li.gd: Tha làraichean an dà eaglais sin ri’m faicinn gus an là an diugh [...]
li.en2: The sites of those two churches can still be seen today [...]
li.ref: Dòmhnall Iain MacDhòmhnaill (1981) Uibhist a Deas 12

li.gd: Chì sinn gun cuala muinntir an dà Chùirt, uair is uair, bho chaochladh dhaoine, gu robh an Iolaire ro fhada gu Tuath anns a’ chùrsa a ghabh i tighinn a steach [...]
li.en2: We will see that the people of the two Courts heard, time and again, from various people, that the Iolaire was too far north in the course it took coming in [...]
li.ref: Tormod Calum Dòmhnallach (1978) Call na h-Iolaire 33

box.p: However, instances of ... na(n) dà ... are occasionally found –

li.gd: [...] tha e coltach gun tainig luibhean talmhainn bho na h-Algae ghorma [...] tha saoghal na dà bhuidhne gu tric co-ionnan.
li.en2: [...] it appears that terrestrial plants came from the green algae [...] the world of the two groups is often identical.
li.ref: Ruaraidh MacThòmais (1976) Bith-Eolas 93

li.gd: Rè nan dà cheud bliadhna an déidh sin, b’iad leabhraichean eaglaiseil is cràbhach gu sònraichte a chaidh a chlo-bhualadh an Suómais [...]
li.en2: During the two hundred years after that, it was mainly ecclesiastical and spiritual books that were printed in Finnish [...]
li.ref: Seòras Hay (1957) ‘Tìr nan Craobh 's nan Loch’ Gairm 20: 305

box.title: definite article + trì
box.p: trì three is a cardinal numeral starting with the dental consonant t(r)-

box.title: definite article + ceithir
box.p: ceithir four is a cardinal numeral starting with the velar consonant c-

box.title: definite article + còig
box.p: còig five is a cardinal numeral starting with the velar consonant c-

box.title: definite article + sia
box.p: sia six is a cardinal numeral starting with the soft sybillant s-

box.title: definite article + seachd
box.p: seachd seven is a cardinal numeral starting with the soft sybillant s-

box.title: definite article + seachd
box.p: ochd eight is a cardinal numeral starting with the vowel o-

box.title: definite article + naoi
box.p: naoi nine is a cardinal numeral starting with the dental consonant n-

box.title: definite article + deich
box.p: deich ten is a cardinal numeral starting with the dental consonant d-

box.title: definite article + ciad
box.p: The ordinal numeral ciad first occurs with the definite article as follows –
The masculine nominative singular form is generally a’ chiad –

li.gd: Thug a’ chiad fhear a-mach sgian agus leum e gu beul an amair.
li.en2: The first man took out a knife and he jumped onto the lip of the bathtub.
li.ref: Dòmhnall Alasdair Dòmhnallach (2001) Sgeulachdan Dhòmhnaill Alasdair 57

box.p: The traditional nominative masculine form an ciad is nowadays archaic –

li.gd: D[à] fhichead bliadhna ’s a ceithir! Is e sin an àireamh bhliadhnachan a bha eadar an ceud Mhòd a bha ann am Baile Bhóid agus am Mòd a chumadh anns a’ bhaile sin am bliadhna.
li.en2: Forty-four years! That was the number of years between the first Mod that was in Rothesay and the Mod that was held in that town this year.
li.ref: Niall MacGhille Sheathanaich (1952) ‘Bho Bhaile Bhóid gu Baile Bhóid’ Gairm 2: 63

box.p: The usual genitive feminine singular form is the regular ... na ciad ...

li.gd: Agus fuaim uabhasach na ciad spaid de dh’ùir.
li.en2: And the terrible sound of the first spade of earth.
li.ref: Iain F. MacLeòid (2005) Na Klondykers 139

li.gd: Aig deireadh na ciad seachdain, air latha brèagha geamhraidh, choisich Muriel a-steach dhan ionad inntinneil.
li.en2: At the end of the first week, on a beautiful winter’s day, Muriel walked into the mental centre.
li.ref: Norma NicLeòid (2006) Dìleas Donn 93

box.p: However, ... a’ chiad ... is often found here –

li.gd: Airson a’ chiad uair thug Alasdair an aire dhan fhear a bha na laighe ann am paiseanadh anns an fhraoch agus e air a cheangal gu teann.
li.en2: For the first time, Alexander paid attention to the man who was lying unconscious in the heather, tightly bound.
li.ref: Iain MacLeòid (1989) Spuirean na h-Iolaire 13

li.gd: Air sgàth na troimh-chéile coimhich seo, bha e eu-comasach dhuinne, feadh a’ cheud seachduinn, rùm ceum coise de’n rathad mhór a shealbhachadh.
li.en2: Because of this strange confusion, it was impossible for us, the whole first week, to get a room within walking distance of the main road.
li.ref: Aonghas Caimbeul (1973) Suathadh Ri Iomadh Rubha 309

box.p: The usual plural forms are the regular na(n) ciad ...

li.gd: Air an dòigh sin, chan fhaigheadh na ciad phlèanaichean an rathad an fheadhainn a bha gan leantainn air an aon t-slighe aon uair is gu leumadh na saighdearan asda.
li.en2: In that way, the first planes would not get in the way of the ones that were following them on the same route once the soldiers had jumped from them.
li.ref: Pol Mac a’ Bhreatunnaich (1987) Air Druim an Eich Sgiathaich 15

li.gd: Thòisich iasgairean nan Eileanan ri dol air chuairt gu Tìr-Mòr a ruith an sgadain an toiseach le bhith ghan gabhail air mar chriutha ann an Steòrnabhagh leis na ciad bhataichean Bucach a thainig air tòir an sgadain anns na h-1820an.
li.en2: Island fishermen started going to the mainland in search of the herring first by being taken on as crew in Stornoway by the first Buckie boats who came looking for herring in the 1820s.
li.ref: Tormod Calum Dòmhnallach (1987) Clann-nighean an Sgadain 50

li.gd: Sgrìobh mi sìos freagairtean nan ciad ochd ceistean mus do dh’èigh mo mhàthair orm.
li.en2: I wrote down the answers of the first eight questions before my mother called on me.
li.ref: Dòmhnall Alasdair Dòmhnallach (2001) Sgeulachdan Dhòmhnaill Alasdair 70

box.p: Again, however, a’ chiad ... is occasionally found here –

li.gd: Ged nach bu sgoilear mo sheanair ’s ann bhuaithe dh’ionnsaich mi a’ chiad fhaclan Laidinn a chunna mi riamh [...]
li.en2: Although my grandfather was not a scholar it was from him that I learned the first words of Latin I ever saw [...]
li.ref: Seonaidh Ailig Mac a’ Phearsain (2011) Steall à Iomadh Lòn 4

li.gd: Airson a’ chiad trì là a bha i aig an taigh cha robh an còrr dhen teaghlach deònach leigeadh le Seonag càil a dhèanamh [...]
li.en2: For the first three days that she was at home the rest of the family were not willing to let Joan do anything [...]
li.ref: Calum MacMhaoilein (1990) A’ Sireadh an Sgadain 84

box.title: definite article + ath
box.p: The ordinal adjective ath next starts with the vowel a- and occurs with the definite article as follows –
The most common nominative masculine form nowadays is an ath ...

li.gd: Chan fhaigheadh a’ chlann-nighean air an càr a leigeil seachad, oir bha an rathad ro chaol agus bha an ath àite airson sin a dhèanamh ceum math air falbh.
li.en2: The girls had not let the car past, because the road was too narrow and the next place for doing that was a good way away.
li.ref: Dòmhnall Alasdair Dòmhnallach (2001) Sgeulachdan Dhòmhnaill Alasdair 75

li.gd: “Uill, dè an ath cheum? Dè tha thu smaoineachadh?”
li.en2: “Well, what is the next step? What do you think?”
li.ref: Tormod MacGill-Eain (2005) Dacha mo Ghaoil 40

box.p: The traditional nominative masculine form an t-ath ... is nowadays archaic –

li.gd: Cha b’ fhada gus an do lean Dùn-àluinn i; agus mu ’n deach an t-ath earrach gu math ’na thigh, thàinig an dithis dachaidh, guala air ghuala, ’s iad pòsda [...]
li.en2: Dunallen soon followed her; and before the next spring had long passed, the pair of them had come home, shoulder to shoulder, married [...]
li.ref: Iain MacCormaic (1912) Dùn-Àluinn 81

box.p: However, when used as a prefix meaning re-, rather than as an adjective, an t-ath is still common (but not ubiquitous) in the nominative masculine –

li.gd: Anns an t-siathamh linn deug thàinig an t-Ath-leasachadh [...]
li.en2: In the sixteenth century the Reformation came [...]
li.ref: Tòmas M. MacCalmain (1967) ‘Ath-aonadh nan Eaglais’ Gairm 58: 140

li.gd: Ghabh an Ath-leasachadh àite ann an 1560.
li.en2: The Reformation took place in 1560.
li.ref: Fionnlagh MacLeòid (2000) Tobraichean sláinte anns na h-Eileanan an Iar 67

box.p: The genitive feminine is generally the expected na h-ath ...

li.gd: Ach trì latha roimhe sin fhuair mi fios gu robh dàil air na coinneamhan chun an robh mi dol chun na h-ath sheachdain.
li.en2: But three days before that I found out that the meetings I was going to were postponed until the next week.
li.ref: Seonaidh Ailig Mac a’ Phearsain (2011) Steall à Iomadh Lòn 309

li.gd: Nuair a ràinig e mullach na h-ath uchdaich chunnaic e bhuaithe solais a’ chàmpa [...]
li.en2: When he reached the top of the next slope he saw the lights from the camp [...]
li.ref: Iain MacLeòid (1992) An Sgaile Dhorcha 69

box.p: But instances of an ath ... are occasionally found here –

li.gd: Fad an ath sheachdain bha e ro thrang ag ionnsachadh mun obair ùir aige airson cus dragh a bhith air mu dheidhinn Diack.
li.en2: All the next week he was too busy learning about his new job to worry too much about Diack.
li.ref: Iain MacLeòid (1989) Spuirean na h-Iolaire 8

box.p: Plural forms are usually, as expected, na h-ath ... (or nan ath ... in the genitive) –

li.gd: Leis an tòir gun tàmh ’na dhéidh, chuir am Prionnsa seachad na h-ath trì mìosan a’ gluasad o àite-falaich gu àite-falaich an Innse-Gall [...]
li.en2: Incessantly pursued, the Prince spent the next three months moving from hiding place to hiding place in the Hebrides [...]
li.ref: Anna Fhriseal (1958) ‘Am Prionnsa ann am Mùideart’ Gairm 25: 64

li.gd: ’Se taighean cloiche den t-seòrsa ris a robh iad cleachdte san t-seann dùthaich a thog na ciad eilthirich [...] ach thòisich na h-ath ghinealachan air na taighean fiodha as minige chithear sa’ chòrr de Chanada is Amaireaga.
li.en2: The first immigrants built stone houses of the kind they were used to in the old country [...] but the following generations adopted the wooden houses frequently seen in the rest of Canada and America.
li.ref: Dòmhnall Iain MacLeòid (1971) ‘Albainn Nuadh’ Gairm 74: 169

box.p: However, plurals in an ath ... are occasionally encountered –

li.gd: B’e an ath fhianuisean aig a’ Chrùn an dà sgrìobhadair-naidheachd a chaidh do’n champ còmhla ri MacRath.
li.en2: The next witnesses for the Crown were the two news reporters who had gone to the camp with MacRae.
li.ref: Tormod Domhnallach (1973) Creach Mhor nam Fiadh 71
